course_name: PSYCH461 - Honours Seminar in Cognitive Neuroscience (0.50)
major_name: Cognitive Science Minor
topics: Instructors: This course will be co-taught by Sophia Tran sophiahtran@uwaterloo.ca & Chantal Trudel chantal.trudel@uwaterloo.ca
The single-case approach in neuropsychology has made a significant contribution to our understanding of the architecture of human cognition.
Studying such patients can provide insights into the brain basis of cognitive processes such as attention, perception, personality, emotion, memory, decision making, and language capacity.

This seminar will first review the basic methodological approach used in single case studies, and the limitations of those approaches, before moving on to a more detailed examination of particular classic cases and their relevance to what we know today.
The goal of the course is to examine classic neuropsychological patient cases in order to understand how these have informed current models of human behaviour.
Examine the relevance and limitations of single cases studies in neuropsychology
Evaluate the impact of classic neuropsychological patient cases on the understanding of current models of human behaviour
Verbally communicate the key points of modern studies in relation to the classic cases studied

This course approaches the design of tasks, tools, products, and systems from a user-centered design perspective.
Emphasis is on the human factors and usability methods, and techniques that can and should be applied throughout the iterative design process.
Major topics include user research methods for usability and user experience, inspection methods, user testing, applied statistical analysis.
SYDE 548 (UCD Methods) approaches the design of tasks, tools, products, and systems from a user-centered design perspective.
Emphasis is on the human factors and usability methods, and techniques that can and should be applied throughout the iterative design process.
Major topics include user research methods for usability and user experience, inspection methods, user testing, and applied statistical analysis.
SYDE 548 User-Centred Design Methods is a technical elective.

topics: Introduction to Optimization Winter 2025
walaa.moursi@uwaterloo.ca
Instructor: Walaa Moursi walaa.moursi@uwaterloo.ca
A broad introduction to the field of optimization, discussing applications, and solution techniques.
Mathematical models for real life applications; algorithms; aspects of computational complexity; geometry; linear programming duality, focusing on the development of algorithms.
Carry out the computations by hand for simple instances of various algorithms such as the Simplex.
Formulate the dual of various linear programs.
Reproduce the main proofs in the course and prove simple related concepts independently.
The simplest models are linear programs where both the constraints and the objective functions are linear.
Even though this may appear at a first glance to be overly restrictive, linear programming algorithms are used widely across most branches of industry.
In these cases, we would like to add the condition that some variables in our linear program take integer values only.
These models are known as integer programs.

Finally, in certain instances, such as portfolio optimization (in financial mathematics), the natural way of formulating the optimization problem may require the use of non-linear constraints, or a non-linear objective function.
In the first part of this course, we will illustrate these various models with examples that arise from real problems.
The Simplex algorithm to solve linear programs will be discussed in some detail and general-purpose integer programming techniques such as branch-and-bound and cutting planes will also be described.
These algorithms while guaranteed to terminate, may in the worst case (and often do in practice) take a prohibitively long time.
An indispensable tool for the design of such fast algorithms is the theory of duality, which will be a main focus of this course.
We will move towards the conclusion of the course with a review of the various techniques used to solve linear and integer programs and by providing a geometric interpretation of these algorithms.
This discussion will lead us to non-linear convex optimization problems.
Also included in this last part of the material are approximation algorithms.

topics: Notice of Recording
Computational Discrete Optimization Winter 2025

Formulations of combinatorial optimization problems, greedy algorithms, dynamic programming, branch-and-bound, cutting plane algorithms, decomposition techniques in integer programming, approximation algorithms.
A discrete optimization problem, broadly speaking, involves a discrete set of feasible solutions and a real-valued objective function that assigns a value to each solution.

Discrete optimization problems are of immense practical importance, are solved every day (sometimes each hour or more frequently) by many Fortune 500 companies;  well-known problems in the class include
This course provides an introduction to the broad field of discrete optimization and covers several classes of commonly used techniques for the design of algorithms, including:
Dynamic programming,
We will discuss algorithmic efficiency and introduce the basics of complexity theory.
For NP-hard problems, we will explore the field of approximation algorithms, which provides efficient methods for computing solutions with guaranteed quality.
Students will complete two practical projects as part of the course, where they will develop, implement, and test algorithms for specific discrete optimization problems.

major_name: Combinatorics and Optimization (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Information Theory and Applications Winter 2024

Basics of information theory; Shannon entropy, KL divergence, and mutual information; basic properties of entropic quantities; chain rule, Pinsker's Inequality, Data Processing Inequality; compression; Channel Coding Theorem; error-correction; applications to combinatorics, optimization, cryptography, and computer science.
Although it was originally developed as a mathematical theory of communication, information theory has found a growing number of applications in seemingly unrelated domains.

Through this course, we will study basic concepts from information theory, properties of entropic quantities, their operational interpretations, and applications in discrete mathematics and computer science.
A tentative list of topics includes:
basic properties of entropic quantities
one-shot and asymptotic compression
Noisy Coding Theorem and error-correction codes
communication complexity of Set Disjointness
applications of error-correction codes
extended linear programming formulations
sample complexity in Learning
Define fundamental entropic quantities
Describe and analyse fundamental communication tasks
Apply information-theoretic concepts and methods in other contexts
Introduction to the course.
Shannon entropy: definition, interpretation, basic properties; prefix-free codes, Kraft Inequality, Source coding theorem; Asymptotic equipartition theorem
Communication over noisy channels, capacity of a channel, examples of simple channels and their capacity; Idea behind channel coding, joint typicality, Channel coding theorem

Error-correction codes, distance of a code, error rate, information rate; Hadamard code, Reed-Solomon code; Efficient encoding and decoding for Reed-Solomon codes; Linear codes, generator matrix, distance, dual code

k-wise independence, construction using Reed-Solomon codes, support size; algorithm for E3-Sat; k-wise independence and distance of dual code, almost k-wise independence, general construction using binary codes
Protocol for Equality revisited; Self-correction and self-testing of Hadamard code; exponential length PCPs for 3-Sat with a constant number of queries

Monotone functions and formulae, monotone formulae for Threshold functions; graph entropy, graph entropy of classes of graphs, properties of graph entropy; min-terms, min-terms of OR and AND of functions, graphs constructed from min-terms; lower bound for Threshold function

Linear programming formulations, polytopes, extensions, the permutahedron, extension complexity; Max-Clique, formulation with the correlation polytope; slack matrix, non-negative rank, Yannakakis Factorization Theorem; facets specified by 0-1 vectors, connection to Set Disjointness; lower bound on non-negative rank via sampling disjoint subsets
Quantum information basics: von Neumann entropy, Holevo Theorem, compression of pure states
Information Theory and its applications in Theory of Computation, course taught by Venkatesan Guruswami and Mahdi Cheraghchi http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~venkatg/teaching/ITCS-spr2013/

topics: Matroid Theory Spring 2023

This is an introductory course on matroid theory, with particular emphasis on graphic matroids and on topics that are applicable to graph theory. The topics include matroid intersection and partition, graphic matroids, matroid connectivity, regular matroids, and representable matroids. Applications include matching, disjoint paths, disjoint spanning trees, the 8-flow theorem for graphs, planarity testing, and recognizing totally unimodular matrices.

Integer Programming is a mathematical program that can be seen as a linear program with the additional requirement that some (or all) of the variables are required to take on integer values.

While linear programming is already very useful in modeling problems and can be solved well using either interior point methods or the simplex method, {\bf Integer programs, or IPs} have a much broader range of applications.
In this course we will explore an upper-level undergraduate/basic graduate introduction to the topic of Integer Programming.

A broad introduction to game theory and its applications to the modeling of competition and cooperation in business, economics, and society.
Classical game theory studies the competitive and cooperative behaviour of rational and self‐interested individuals in strategic environments.
It speciﬁcally develops beautiful analytic tools to analyze and model situations in which a person’s welfare is a function not only of their own actions, but also those of others.
This course is meant to be a broad and mathematical introduction to game theory and its appications.

course_name: CO481 - Introduction to Quantum Information Processing (0.50)
major_name: Combinatorics and Optimization (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Introduction to Quantum Information Processing Winter 2024

Basics of computational complexity; basics of quantum information; quantum phenomena; quantum circuits and universality; relationship between quantum and classical complexity classes; simple quantum algorithms; quantum Fourier transform; Shor factoring algorithm; Grover search algorithm; physical realization of quantum computation; error-correction and fault-tolerance; quantum key distribution.
This course aims to give a basic foundation in the field of quantum information processing (often just called "quantum computing").

QIP is a multidisciplinary subject and therefore this course will introduce fundamental concepts in theoretical computer science and physics that will enable students to pursue further study in various aspects of QIP.
Prerequisites: A solid background in basic linear algebra (e.g. a good performance in MATH 235 or MATH 114) is necessary.

major_name: Combinatorics and Optimization (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Complex Analysis Winter 2025
Complex numbers provide the natural setting in which to study differentiable functions.

Cauchy's theorem plays a central role in this subject, and many important results follow from it: Cauchy's integral formula, the theory of Taylor and Laurent series, Cauchy's residue theorem, the argument principle, the fundamental theorem of algebra, the maximum modulus theorem, Mittag-Lefler expansions, and Weierstrass products.

We’ll start the course with a basic review of complex numbers, and the complex exponential and logarithm, complex analytic functions, and make our way towards Cauchy's theorem and its wonderful consequences.
My lectures will draw on a number of books and sources, but I recommend Knopp's Elements of the Theory of Functions, and his Theory of Functions Parts I and II.
Another reference is Marsden and Hoffman's Basic Complex Analysis.

major_name: Computational Mathematics (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Introduction to Differential Equations Winter 2025
Solving linear differential equations: first- and second-order scalar equations and first-order vector equations.
The main purpose of the course is to explore how first and second order differential equations (DEs) are used to model physical systems and predict their behaviour.
first order linear DE models of compartment problems, atomic decay, and bodies in motion;
first order separable DE models of population growth;
a first order exact DE model of the electric dipole;
second order linear DE models for oscillatory systems such as mass-spring-damper systems and electrical circuits;
second order nonlinear DE models for suspended cables and rocket motion;
linear vector DE models of multiple compartment problems and species interactions.
Both analytical solution techniques and qualitative methods (direction field analysis, dimensional analysis, and phase portraits) will be presented as ways to gain information about system behaviour.
We will investigate conditions for existence, uniqueness, and continuity of solutions of both first and second order initial value problems, and for systems in the plane.
Maple will be used to generate numerical and graphical solutions, to illustrate concepts graphically, and to explore model behaviour.
increase your comprehension of some of the many ways that differential equations can help us understand the real world;
develop your ability to understand a mathematical model for a specific situation;
explore analytical and qualitative solution methods for first and second order differential equations, and the use of Maple; and

topics: Introduction to Optimization Winter 2025
walaa.moursi@uwaterloo.ca
Instructor: Walaa Moursi walaa.moursi@uwaterloo.ca
A broad introduction to the field of optimization, discussing applications, and solution techniques.
Mathematical models for real life applications; algorithms; aspects of computational complexity; geometry; linear programming duality, focusing on the development of algorithms.
Carry out the computations by hand for simple instances of various algorithms such as the Simplex.
Formulate the dual of various linear programs.
Reproduce the main proofs in the course and prove simple related concepts independently.
The simplest models are linear programs where both the constraints and the objective functions are linear.
Even though this may appear at a first glance to be overly restrictive, linear programming algorithms are used widely across most branches of industry.
In these cases, we would like to add the condition that some variables in our linear program take integer values only.
These models are known as integer programs.

Finally, in certain instances, such as portfolio optimization (in financial mathematics), the natural way of formulating the optimization problem may require the use of non-linear constraints, or a non-linear objective function.
In the first part of this course, we will illustrate these various models with examples that arise from real problems.
The Simplex algorithm to solve linear programs will be discussed in some detail and general-purpose integer programming techniques such as branch-and-bound and cutting planes will also be described.
These algorithms while guaranteed to terminate, may in the worst case (and often do in practice) take a prohibitively long time.
An indispensable tool for the design of such fast algorithms is the theory of duality, which will be a main focus of this course.
We will move towards the conclusion of the course with a review of the various techniques used to solve linear and integer programs and by providing a geometric interpretation of these algorithms.
This discussion will lead us to non-linear convex optimization problems.
Also included in this last part of the material are approximation algorithms.

course_name: AMATH343 - Discrete Models in Applied Mathematics (0.50)
major_name: Computational Mathematics (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Discrete Models in Applied Mathematics Fall 2023
Difference equations and discrete dynamical systems.
Mathematical models are taken from ecology, biology, economics, and other fields.

Many such systems evolve over continuous time and can be modelled by differential equations, however, there are some systems for which the evolution is more appropriately described using discrete time intervals - for example, plant and animal populations where breeding and other effects can be assumed to take place at particular times of the year.
As with differential equations, difference equations can be classified as linear difference equations and nonlinear difference equations.
First, we will examine linear difference equations and a number of standard methods to solve them.
The asymptotic behaviour of nonlinear systems can be quite complicated, leading to such things as “bifurcations,” “chaos,” and “fractals.”
A few simple models will be studied in order to understand certain aspects of this behaviour.
We will explore the notion of “fractal dimension” as well as some simple methods of generating fractal sets.
Time permitting, we will look at iterated function systems (IFS), a simple, yet powerful, geometric method of generating and studying fractal sets.

topics: Introduction to Mathematical Biology Winter 2025
Email: cbauch@uwaterloo.ca

Students develop an intuition for describing the biological world in mathematical terms, by writing down and analyzing mathematical models of biological systems.
Students also collaborate in team projects where they are required to construct, analyze and interpret models using mathematical software packages, and present their work to the class.
Biology prerequisites are not necessary, but knowledge of differential equations and matrix algebra is required.

Sampling of material offered: ecology (exponential growth models, logistic growth models, predator-prey dynamics, competition models); epidemiology (compartmental models of childhood infectious diseases, influenza); microbiology (slime mold growth; cell cycles); population genetics; and physiology.

Techniques learned will include stability analysis of discrete-time models and ordinary differential equations, phase plane methods and qualitative solutions, travelling wave solutions of partial differential equations, and use of mathematical software for modelling.
In some populations, dynamics can be broken down into discrete stages (for instance, insects that reproduce only during a particular time of year).
In these cases, difference equations that describe time is a discrete way are appropriate models.
We will discuss the theory of linear and nonlinear difference equations and their applications in biology.
We will introduce the topic of ordinary differential equation models and their formulation and analysis in the context of biological problems.

In both parts I and II, we will emphasise how appropriate assumptions can simplify the biological problem, how important variables can be identified and how difference/differential equations can be tailored to describe the essential features of a biological process.
After defining the problem and formulating a consistent set of equations, we will turn to the analysis of their solutions.
Introduction to Spatially Distributed Systems, Partial Differential Equations and Other Methodologies.
In order to analyze them it is necessary to develop models that capture spatial structure of real populations.
Partial differential equations can provide means for modeling spatially structured biological processes.
We will briefly introduce these methodologies and demonstrate how they can be applied to study spatio-temporal dynamics of biological phenomena.
